text: Curious if any of you on the agency side charge clients a different price for refreshing content your agency produced vs. refreshing existing content that your agency _didn’t_ produce. Like, if a client came to you and said, “We want to refresh these 20 URLs”, would you charge them differently than if you had produced that copy to begin with?

elements.text: Curious if any of you on the agency side charge clients a different price for refreshing content your agency produced vs. refreshing existing content that your agency
didn’t
produce. Like, if a client came to you and said, “We want to refresh these 20 URLs”, would you charge them differently than if you had produced that copy to begin with?

text: It's not something that our agency has done to my knowledge. It's not something I'd even thought of before so now I'm interested to see what type of answers you get!

elements.text: It's not something that our agency has done to my knowledge. It's not something I'd even thought of before so now I'm interested to see what type of answers you get!

text:
I wouldn't differentiate by who created it originally, I would differentiate by how far off it is from expectation.

A piece of content that is 500 words on a topic that requires comprehensiveness is basically writing from scratch - I would charge it as so.

But upgrading a piece of content that is already well organized and fairly substantial is way less work. EG "we basically added two paragraphs to better match intent, and created custom graphics" might be half the work of a full production piece.

Often I would guess that most of your upgrades to content your team built fall into the second bucket, and many of the client's legacy content fits into the first bucket?

So I'd do a quick audit on the 20 urls, bucket them between 'full scope' and 'half scope', and bill at 100% and 50% rates to keep things simple.

text: Anyone have a really _stellar_ website copy freelancer they recommend for one-off projects? I'm looking for a _highly experienced_ copywriter who specializes in B2B website copy specifically...message me if you know of someone. Thanks!

elements.text: Anyone have a really
stellar
website copy freelancer they recommend for one-off projects? I'm looking for a
highly experienced
copywriter who specializes in B2B website copy specifically...message me if you know of someone. Thanks!

text:
> I would guess that most of your upgrades to content your team built fall into the second bucket, and many of the client’s legacy content fits into the first bucket?
This is 100% what I’m sorting out.

I’ve been talking this out with our COO. Even if there are extensive rewrites involved, refreshes still need to preserve parts of the original content. Hard to define that.

What’s consistent (for our agency, anyway), is that no matter if we’re doing a new or refreshed piece of content, we always start with a target keyword. That keyword informs all of our research processes for new _and_ refreshed content. So it makes sense to us to treat everything as one price (for new or existing content, again, because the processes are generally the same).

For one-off refresh deliverables, I’m inclined to work with our stakeholder to make estimates if a blog doesn’t warrant an entire rewrite, and rather, some improvements to formatting, an additional graf, and internal links. But on the whole, I’m leaning toward pricing refreshes as though they’re a new piece.

text:
This is why I like the 100%/50% cost approach.

We would tell clients to expect 100% normal project rate most of the time, but when we encountered a batch where we were truly polishing up decent content, we had an established point to drop back to and say "_we can do 50% of normal rate because we're doing most of the steps except for building core outline and content._"

Definitely case-by-case, client-by-client. Every project is a little different.

"

joel klettke!
